Abstract

Federated learning is a decentralized machine learning framework wherein not all clients are able to participate in each round. An emerging line of research is devoted to tackling arbitrary client unavailability. Existing theoretical analysis imposes restrictive structural assumptions on the unavailability patterns, and their proposed algorithms were tailored to those assumptions.

In this paper, we relax those assumptions and consider adversarial client unavailability. To quantify the degrees of client unavailability, we use the notion of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-adversary dropout fraction. For both non-convex and strongly-convex global objectives, we show that simple variants of FedAvg or FedProx, albeit completely agnostic to ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, converge to an estimation error on the order of ϵ​(G2+σ2)italic-ϵsuperscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2\epsilon(G^{2}+\sigma^{2}), where G𝐺G is a heterogeneity parameter and σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is the noise level. We prove that this estimation error is minimax-optimal. We also show that the variants of FedAvg or FedProx have convergence speeds O​(1/T)𝑂1𝑇O(1/\sqrt{T}) for non-convex objectives and O​(1/T)𝑂1𝑇O(1/T) for strongly-convex objectives, both of which are the best possible for any first-order method that only has access to noisy gradients. Our proofs build upon a tight analysis of the selection bias that persists in the entire learning process. We validate our theoretical prediction through numerical experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets.

1 Introduction

Federated learning is a decentralized machine learning framework, wherein the clients coordinate with a parameter server without disclosing local data [MMR+17, KMA+21]. Cross-device federated learning is often massive in scale, making full client participation impractical [MMR+17]. Most existing work either assumes that client unavailability follows benign distributions [MMR+17, LHY+20, RZLJW21, PD20] or that the parameter server can arbitrarily recruit participants [CWJ22], i.e., a client reached out by the parameter server must follow its computation requests. However, these assumptions rarely hold in practice unless the training environments are under good control.

As pointed out in the seminal work [MMR+17], real-world federated learning is often deployed in non-controllable environments, and the availability of a client depends (in a complicated way) on multiple time-varying factors such as external interruptions and hardware/software status. For instance, when the clients are mobile devices, a client may not respond to a computation request if disconnected from WiFi. As another example, a client may suddenly abort the training process due to interruptions caused by low battery and other prioritized tasks.

As such, there is a recent surge of interest in studying arbitrary client unavailability [GHZH21, WJ22, YND+20, YZKL22]. Despite that they collectively laid a solid foundation in this direction, this line of work still imposes stringent structural assumptions on unavailability patterns such as regularized participation [WJ22], bounded inactive periods [YND+20, YZKL22, GHZH21], and asymptotic unbounded inactive periods [GHZH21]. Existing algorithm designs and analysis are tailored to those specific assumptions; see Section 2 for details. It is easy to find patterns that violate the aforementioned assumptions. For example, a client may be inactive for a while and become active at some carefully chosen time in order to disturb the learning process. Overall, there is a wide spectrum of client unavailability modes that are not well covered by existing works.

In this paper, we relax those structural assumptions and consider adversarial client unavailability. Specifically, in each round first the parameter server randomly samples K𝐾K clients, and then a system adversary can – based on all the information up to now – adaptively select a subset of sampled clients to be non-responsive. To quantify the degrees of client unavailability, we use the notion of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-adversary dropout fraction. We show that simple variants of the standard FedAvg or FedProx algorithms, albeit agnostic to the degree of client unavailability ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, turn out to be optimal. We further validate our theoretical prediction through numerical experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets.

Concretely, we study a canonical setup in which the goal is to minimize F​(θ)≜∑i=1Mwi​Fi​(θ)≜𝐹𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝜃F(\theta)\triangleq\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}F_{i}(\theta) when only noisy stochastic gradients are available, where wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} is the weight and Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} is the local objective of client i∈[M]𝑖delimited-[]𝑀i\in[M]. The local data is non-IID yet satisfies the standard (B,G)𝐵𝐺(B,G)-heterogeneity condition [KMA+21] (formally described in Assumption 1). Our main theoretical results can be summarized succinctly in the following informal theorem.

Theorem 1 (Informal).

When F𝐹F is non-convex, let ℛ​(θ^):=‖∇F​(θ^)‖2assignℛ^𝜃superscriptnorm∇𝐹^𝜃2{\mathcal{R}}(\widehat{\theta}):=\|\nabla F(\widehat{\theta})\|^{2}; when F𝐹F is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex, let ℛ​(θ^):=μ2​‖θ^−θ∗‖22assignℛ^𝜃superscript𝜇2superscriptsubscriptnorm^𝜃superscript𝜃22{\mathcal{R}}(\widehat{\theta}):=\mu^{2}\|\widehat{\theta}-\theta^{*}\|_{2}^{2}, where θ∗=arg⁡min⁡F​(θ)superscript𝜃𝐹𝜃\theta^{*}=\arg\min F(\theta). Let σ𝜎\sigma be the average noise level of the stochastic gradients. Then

infθ^sup𝒜supF1,⋯,FM𝔼​[ℛ​(θ^)]≍ϵ​(G2+σ2),asymptotically-equalssubscriptinfimum^𝜃subscriptsupremum𝒜subscriptsupremumsubscript𝐹1⋯subscript𝐹𝑀𝔼delimited-[]ℛ^𝜃italic-ϵsuperscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2\inf_{\widehat{\theta}}\sup_{{\mathcal{A}}}\sup_{F_{1},\cdots,F_{M}}\mathbb{E}\left[{\mathcal{R}}(\widehat{\theta})\right]~{}\asymp~{}{\epsilon\left(G^{2}+\sigma^{2}\right)},

where supF1,⋯,FMsubscriptsupremumsubscript𝐹1⋯subscript𝐹𝑀\sup_{F_{1},\cdots,F_{M}} is taken over all local objectives that collectively satisfy the (B,G)𝐵𝐺(B,G)-heterogeneity condition, 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}} is all adversarial client unavailability subject to ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-adversary dropout fraction, and infθ^subscriptinfimum^𝜃\inf_{\widehat{\theta}} is taken over all algorithms θ^^𝜃\widehat{\theta} that have only access to noisy local gradients.

  • ∙∙\bullet

    The achievability of O​(ϵ​(G2+σ2))𝑂italic-ϵsuperscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2O(\epsilon\left(G^{2}+\sigma^{2}\right)) is proved in Section 4.1 by analyzing variants of FedAvg or FedProx. We also characterize their convergence speeds and show that ℛ​(θ^t)ℛsubscript^𝜃𝑡{\mathcal{R}}(\widehat{\theta}_{t}) approaches O​(ϵ​(G2+σ2))𝑂italic-ϵsuperscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2O(\epsilon\left(G^{2}+\sigma^{2}\right)) at a speed of O​(1/T)𝑂1𝑇O(1/\sqrt{T}) for non-convex functions (with general form in Theorem 2 and explicit speeds in Corollary 1) and O​(1/T)𝑂1𝑇O(1/T) for strongly-convex functions (Theorem 3). These convergence speeds are on par with the centralized settings [GL13, NJLS09], and are the best possible for any first-order method that has only access to noisy gradients [ACD+22, GHZH21].

  • ∙∙\bullet

    The impossibility of o​(ϵ​(G2+σ2))𝑜italic-ϵsuperscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2o(\epsilon\left(G^{2}+\sigma^{2}\right)) is shown in Section 5 (Theorem 4).

Interestingly, among the two heterogeneity parameters B𝐵B and G𝐺G, only G𝐺G appears in the estimation error O​(ϵ​(G2+σ2))𝑂italic-ϵsuperscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2O(\epsilon\left(G^{2}+\sigma^{2}\right)). Our analysis reveals that B𝐵B instead influences the convergence speed.

It is worth noting that our adversarial client unavailability model can be viewed as a special case of Byzantine attacks [Lyn96, BDPPBT19]. Nevertheless, existing Byzantine-resilient results are not applicable to our problem. A distinctive feature of our problem is that the set of faulty clients is changing over time, which results in selection bias that may accumulate throughout the entire process. Specifically, at every round the adversary can inspect all the local gradients and all the past information to adaptively select a subset of clients to be non-responsive. This selection bias is largely overlooked in existing Byzantine-resilient FL literature. We defer detailed discussions to Appendix A.

2 Related work

Random client unavailability. Random client unavailability has received intensive attention in recent years [KMA+21]. Previous studies [MMR+17, LHY+20, YL22] assumed that the parameter server can successfully recruit K𝐾K clients uniformly at random or proportionally to clients’ local data volume in each round. Such client sampling methods are not applicable when some clients are not responsive. Additionally, the analysis on the fast responses [LHY+20, PD20, KMA+21, WJ22] assumed that each client responds with a known probability. A generalized version of random client unavailability patterns is proposed in [RZLJW21], where during each round the number of local updates at a client follows a distribution with support on {0,1,⋯,s}01⋯𝑠\{0,1,\cdots,s\}, where s𝑠s is the number of local updates.

Arbitrary client unavailability. Only a handful of work exists on arbitrary client unavailability [YND+20, GHZH21, WJ22, YZKL22, CWJ22]. Both [YND+20] and [CWJ22] focus on controllable environments, where every client sampled by the parameter server must respond accordingly. [YND+20] considered non-convex optimization with one-step local updates, and proposed FedLaAvg which was shown to be resilient to bounded inactive periods. When the local objectives are strongly-convex, [CWJ22] showed that convergence can be expedited if the parameter server strategically recruits clients based on the current global model. In comparison, we consider the practical scenario where some sampled clients fail to respond to the computation requests. Non-controllable environments were investigated more recently [GHZH21, WJ22, YZKL22]. [GHZH21] considered both strongly-convex and non-convex objectives, and proposed MIFA which shares similar ideas as FedLaAvg yet requires full client participation in the first round. For strongly-convex objectives, [GHZH21] characterized the unavailability patterns that each client needs to obey, which require clients to be frequently available during the early training stage (i.e., when t𝑡t is small). For non-convex objectives, MIFA was shown to tolerate bounded inactive periods [GHZH21]. Assuming that the client unavailability pattern is known and the local objectives F1,⋯,FMsubscript𝐹1⋯subscript𝐹𝑀F_{1},\cdots,F_{M} satisfy the (B,G)𝐵𝐺(B,G)-heterogeneity condition with B=0𝐵0B=0. [WJ22] came up with a unified analysis for a generalized version of FedAvg wherein the global model updates are amplified periodically. Unfortunately, their analysis does not go through for adversarial client unavailability because of the bias introduced by the adversarial selection of the non-responsive clients. [YZKL22] considered an interesting setup wherein, instead of passively waiting to be recruited, the clients decide on when and how to participate in federated learning. However, clients in [YZKL22] are restricted to make decisions without using any historical information in order to ensure some independence property. Without such independence, the conditional expectation involved in the proof of [YZKL22, Lemma 2] is biased; hence Lemma 2 no longer holds. Similarly, the derivation of the term A1subscript𝐴1A_{1} in their proof of Theorem 4 breaks down.

3 Problem setup

Learning objective. A parameter server and M𝑀M clients collaboratively minimize

minθ∈ℝd⁡F​(θ)=∑i=1Mwi​Fi​(θ),subscript𝜃superscriptℝ𝑑𝐹𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝜃\displaystyle\min_{\theta\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}}F(\theta)=\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}F_{i}(\theta), (1)

where Fi​(θ)=𝔼z∼𝒟i​[ℓi​(θ;z)]subscript𝐹𝑖𝜃subscript𝔼similar-to𝑧subscript𝒟𝑖delimited-[]subscriptℓ𝑖𝜃𝑧F_{i}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{z\sim{\mathcal{D}}_{i}}[\ell_{i}(\theta;z)] is the local objective, wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} is the weight, 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖{\mathcal{D}}_{i} is the local data distribution, and ℓi​(θ;z)subscriptℓ𝑖𝜃𝑧\ell_{i}(\theta;z) is a loss function. The local datasets can be unbalanced across clients. Let nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} denote the number of data points generated from the unknown 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖{\mathcal{D}}_{i} at every round by client i𝑖i, and N=∑i=1Mni𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑛𝑖N=\sum_{i=1}^{M}n_{i} be the total number of data points drawn at every round. Following the literature [LSZ+20, LHY+20, YL22, KKM+20] we adopt the following bounded dissimilarity assumption.

Assumption 1 (Bounded dissimilarity).

We say that (wi,Fi)subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖(w_{i},F_{i}) satisfies the (B,G)𝐵𝐺(B,G)-bounded dissimilarity condition for B≥1𝐵1B\geq 1 and G≥0𝐺0G\geq 0 if ∑i∈[M]wi​‖∇Fi​(θ)‖22≤B2​‖∇F​(θ)‖22+G2subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖superscriptsubscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝜃22superscript𝐵2superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐹𝜃22superscript𝐺2\sum_{i\in[M]}w_{i}\left\|{\nabla F_{i}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq B^{2}\left\|{\nabla F(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}+G^{2}.

When the local datasets are IID (i.e., 𝒟i=𝒟jsubscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝒟𝑗{\mathcal{D}}_{i}={\mathcal{D}}_{j} for any i,j∈[M]𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑀i,j\in[M]), it holds that B=1𝐵1B=1 and G=0𝐺0G=0 as Fi=Fsubscript𝐹𝑖𝐹F_{i}=F for all clients. When data is non-IID, more stringent forms of bounded dissimilarity assumptions are popular in the existing literature on arbitrary client unavailability and Byzantine resilience. For example, [YND+20] and [CWJ22] assumed bounded gradients, i.e., ∑i∈[M]wi​‖∇Fi​(θ)‖22≤G2subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖superscriptsubscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝜃22superscript𝐺2\sum_{i\in[M]}w_{i}\left\|{\nabla F_{i}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq G^{2}. Both [WJ22] and [YZKL22] assumed ∑i∈[M]wi​‖∇Fi​(θ)−∇F​(θ)‖22≤G2subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖superscriptsubscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝜃∇𝐹𝜃22superscript𝐺2\sum_{i\in[M]}w_{i}\left\|{\nabla F_{i}(\theta)-\nabla F(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq G^{2}. Byzantine resilience was shown in [KHJ22, AFG+23] assuming either G=0𝐺0G=0 or ∑i∈[M]wi​‖∇Fi​(θ)−∇F​(θ)‖22≤G2subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖superscriptsubscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝜃∇𝐹𝜃22superscript𝐺2\sum_{i\in[M]}w_{i}\left\|{\nabla F_{i}(\theta)-\nabla F(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq G^{2}.

Adversarial Client Unavailability. In each round t𝑡t, first the parameter server uniformly at random selects a set 𝒮~t⊂[M]subscript~𝒮𝑡delimited-[]𝑀\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}\subset[M] of K𝐾K clients without replacement. Each client i∈𝒮~t𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑡i\in\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t} draws a fresh sample zi,tsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑡z_{i,t} of size nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} from the local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖{\mathcal{D}}_{i}. Let p=K/M𝑝𝐾𝑀p=K/M. Similar client selection was considered in [MMR+17, KMA+21, JSNJ22]. Then the adversary adaptively chooses the set 𝒮t⊂𝒮~tsubscript𝒮𝑡subscript~𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}_{t}\subset\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t} of participating clients. The adversary’s choice of 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}_{t} may depend on the sets of local data points {zi,τ:τ≤t,i∈[M]}conditional-setsubscript𝑧𝑖𝜏formulae-sequence𝜏𝑡𝑖delimited-[]𝑀\{z_{i,\tau}:\tau\leq t,i\in[M]\} drawn by all clients up to time t𝑡t and the sets of participating clients {𝒮τ,τ≤t−1}subscript𝒮𝜏𝜏𝑡1\{{\mathcal{S}}_{\tau},\tau\leq t-1\} chosen previously. We also allow the adversary to have total access to all system parameters including nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} and local objective functions Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i}. In other words, the adversary is fully aware of everything that happened up to time t𝑡t. Such adaptive choice of “faulty” clients is standard in distributed computing literature [Lyn96, BDPPBT19, CM16].

To further quantify the degrees of client unavailability, below we impose an upper bound on the total number of data points that are dropped by the adversary at every round t.𝑡t.

Assumption 2 (ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-adversary dropout fraction).

∑i∈𝒮~t∖𝒮tni≤ϵ​K​NM,∀t.subscript𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑡subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑛𝑖italic-ϵ𝐾𝑁𝑀for-all𝑡\sum_{i\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}\setminus{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}n_{i}\leq\epsilon\frac{KN}{M},\quad\forall t.

Roughly speaking, since 𝔼​[∑i∈𝒮~tni]=K​N/M𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑡subscript𝑛𝑖𝐾𝑁𝑀\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{i\in\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}}n_{i}\right]=KN/M,  Assumption 2 says that on average at most ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon fraction of the sampled data points can be further dropped out by the adversary. In the data balanced setting where ni=N/Msubscript𝑛𝑖𝑁𝑀n_{i}=N/M for all i𝑖i, Assumption 2 simplifies to |𝒮~t∖𝒮t|≤ϵ​Ksubscript~𝒮𝑡subscript𝒮𝑡italic-ϵ𝐾|\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}\setminus{\mathcal{S}}_{t}|\leq\epsilon K, that is, at most ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-fraction of clients in 𝒮~tsubscript~𝒮𝑡\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t} are non-responsive.

4 Algorithms and convergence guarantees

Algorithms. We analyze variants of FedAvg and FedProx in this section. Assumptions. In the sequel, we analyze the convergence property of the algorithms. We assume throughout this section that each local gradient function ∇ℓi,t​(θ)∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta) is Lisubscript𝐿𝑖L_{i}-Lipschitz for all t𝑡t, that is,

‖∇ℓi,t​(u)−∇ℓi,t​(v)‖2≤Li​‖u−v‖2.subscriptnorm∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝑢∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝑣2subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptnorm𝑢𝑣2\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(u)-\nabla\ell_{i,t}(v)}\right\|_{2}\leq L_{i}\left\|{u-v}\right\|_{2}. (3)

Such smoothness condition is commonly used in the convergence analysis of federated learning algorithms (see e.g. [LSZ+20, YL22]). Define L≜maxi∈[M]⁡Li≜𝐿subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑀subscript𝐿𝑖L\triangleq\max_{i\in[M]}L_{i}. For FedProx, we additionally assume that

λmin​(∇2ℓi,t​(θ))≥−L−,∀i,and​∀t.subscript𝜆superscript∇2subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃subscript𝐿for-all𝑖andfor-all𝑡\lambda_{\min}(\nabla^{2}\ell_{i,t}(\theta))\geq-L_{-},\quad\forall i,~{}\text{and}~{}\forall t. (4)

The condition is commonly adopted in the analysis of proximal gradient descent [LSZ+20]. It ensures that, using a sufficiently small ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t}, the objective function in FedProx is strongly convex, and hence the solution is unique and can be efficiently found.

Let ℱtsubscriptℱ𝑡{\mathcal{F}}_{t} denote the filtration generated by the sequence {zi,τ,𝒮τ:τ≤t−1,i∈[M]}.conditional-setsubscript𝑧𝑖𝜏subscript𝒮𝜏formulae-sequence𝜏𝑡1𝑖delimited-[]𝑀\{z_{i,\tau},{\mathcal{S}}_{\tau}:\tau\leq t-1,i\in[M]\}. Then θt∈ℱtsubscript𝜃𝑡subscriptℱ𝑡\theta_{t}\in{\mathcal{F}}_{t}. It follows from our problem setup that 𝒮~tsubscript~𝒮𝑡\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t} and zi,tsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑡z_{i,t} for i∈[M]𝑖delimited-[]𝑀i\in[M] are independent of ℱtsubscriptℱ𝑡{\mathcal{F}}_{t}. We assume the regularity condition that ∇ℓi,t​(θt)∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t}) is an unbiased estimate of ∇Fi​(θt)∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜃𝑡\nabla F_{i}(\theta_{t}) conditioned on ℱtsubscriptℱ𝑡{\mathcal{F}}_{t}:

𝔼​[∇ℓi,t​(θt)∣ℱt]=Fi​(θt),𝔼delimited-[]conditional∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡subscriptℱ𝑡subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜃𝑡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})\mid{\mathcal{F}}_{t}\right]=F_{i}(\theta_{t}), (5)
𝔼​[‖∇ℓi,t​(θt)−Fi​(θt)‖22∣ℱt]≤σi2.𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptnorm∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜃𝑡22subscriptℱ𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})-F_{i}(\theta_{t})}\right\|_{2}^{2}\mid{\mathcal{F}}_{t}\right]\leq\sigma_{i}^{2}. (6)

Let σ2=∑i=1Mwi​σi2superscript𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2\sigma^{2}=\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}\sigma_{i}^{2} denote the average noise level.

4.1 Non-convex functions

Theorem 2.

Let Fmin≜infθF​(θ)≜subscript𝐹subscriptinfimum𝜃𝐹𝜃F_{\min}\triangleq\inf_{\theta}F(\theta). Suppose that ϵ​B<0.8italic-ϵ𝐵0.8\sqrt{\epsilon}B<0.8. We remark that the assumption ϵ​B<0.8italic-ϵ𝐵0.8\sqrt{\epsilon}B<0.8 is to some extent necessary. Intuitively, if B𝐵B gets larger, Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i}’s become more dissimilar and hence fewer adversarial dropouts can be tolerated. See Remark 4 in Appendix D for more detailed discussion.

Below we show the convergence rates under some concrete schemes of the learning rate based on Theorem 2. In the first case, ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} depends on the eventual termination time T𝑇T, which may be chosen based on a prescribed level of optimality; in the second case, ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} is independent of T𝑇T, so the program can be executed indefinitely. We only present the results for the FedAvg, and the results for the FedProx are entirely analogous yet with s=1𝑠1s=1. Let Δ=F​(θ0)−FminΔ𝐹subscript𝜃0subscript𝐹\Delta=F(\theta_{0})-F_{\min}. Recall that p=K/M𝑝𝐾𝑀p=K/M.

Corollary 1.

For FedAvg: Choose ηt=110​β​L​B2∧1β​p​T​L​(G+σ)subscript𝜂𝑡110𝛽𝐿superscript𝐵21𝛽𝑝𝑇𝐿𝐺𝜎\eta_{t}=\frac{1}{10\beta LB^{2}}\wedge\frac{1}{\beta\sqrt{pTL}(G+\sigma)}. Then

𝔼​‖∇F​(θR)‖22≤O​(ϵ​(G+σ)2)+O​(Δ​L​B2/(p​s​T)+(Δ+1)​(G+σ)​s​L/p​T).𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝜃𝑅22𝑂italic-ϵsuperscript𝐺𝜎2𝑂Δ𝐿superscript𝐵2𝑝𝑠𝑇Δ1𝐺𝜎𝑠𝐿𝑝𝑇\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\|{\nabla F(\theta_{R})}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq O\left(\epsilon\left(G+\sigma\right)^{2}\right)+O\left(\Delta LB^{2}/(psT)+(\Delta+1)\left(G+\sigma\right)s\sqrt{L/pT}\right).

Choose ηt=η0t+1subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝜂0𝑡1\eta_{t}=\frac{\eta_{0}}{\sqrt{t+1}} for all t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0, where η0=110​β​L​B2∧1β​p​L​(G+σ)subscript𝜂0110𝛽𝐿superscript𝐵21𝛽𝑝𝐿𝐺𝜎\eta_{0}=\frac{1}{10\beta LB^{2}}\wedge\frac{1}{\beta\sqrt{pL}(G+\sigma)}. Then

The rate O​(1/T)𝑂1𝑇O(1/\sqrt{T}) matches that of the standard stochastic gradient descent for optimizing non-convex functions [GL13]. In fact, the rate O​(1/T)𝑂1𝑇O(1/\sqrt{T}) is the best possible for any first-order method that has only access to noisy gradients (see e.g. [ACD+22, Theorem 3]). See Appendix B for details.

Remark 1.

The random termination time R𝑅R in Theorem 2 is not revealed to the adversary. Alternatively, the parameter server can choose a random point θRsubscript𝜃𝑅\theta_{R} after running the program for T𝑇T global rounds. The statement is equivalent to the upper bound of some properly weighted average of gradient norms during the T𝑇T rounds. Furthermore, it implies the same upper bound for the minimum gradient norm over those rounds;

4.2 Convex functions

The global objective function F𝐹F is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex for some μ>0𝜇0\mu>0 if

⟨∇F​(x)−∇F​(y),x−y⟩≥μ​‖x−y‖22,∀x,y.∇𝐹𝑥∇𝐹𝑦𝑥𝑦𝜇superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑥𝑦22for-all𝑥𝑦\displaystyle\left\langle\nabla F(x)-\nabla F(y),x-y\right\rangle\geq\mu\left\|{x-y}\right\|_{2}^{2},\quad\forall x,y. (9)

It is worth noting that the convergence results here only require the global objective F𝐹F to be strongly convex; each local objective Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} can still be non-convex. This is slightly more relaxed compared with what is typically imposed in the federated learning literature. For instance, the local population functions Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} at every client are assumed to be μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex in [LHY+20, KKM+20, GHZH21].

Theorem 3.

Suppose that F𝐹F is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex and B​ϵ<0.8​μL𝐵italic-ϵ0.8𝜇𝐿B\sqrt{\epsilon}<0.8\frac{\mu}{L}. For FedAvg, suppose that Assumptions 1 and 2 hold, and choose ηt=θ/(t+γ)subscript𝜂𝑡𝜃𝑡𝛾\eta_{t}=\theta/(t+\gamma) for constants θ,γ𝜃𝛾\theta,\gamma such that ρ=c​β​p​s​θ​μ>1𝜌𝑐𝛽𝑝𝑠𝜃𝜇1\rho=c\beta ps\theta\mu>1 and ηt≤μ10​β​s​L2​B2subscript𝜂𝑡𝜇10𝛽𝑠superscript𝐿2superscript𝐵2\eta_{t}\leq\frac{\mu}{10\beta sL^{2}B^{2}} for all t𝑡t. For FedProx, suppose that Assumptions 1, 2 and the condition in Eq.(4) hold, and choose ηt=θ/(t+γ)subscript𝜂𝑡𝜃𝑡𝛾\eta_{t}=\theta/(t+\gamma) for constants θ,γ𝜃𝛾\theta,\gamma such that ρ=c​β​p​θ​μ>1𝜌𝑐𝛽𝑝𝜃𝜇1\rho=c\beta p\theta\mu>1 and ηt≤μ10​β​L2​B2∧110​L−subscript𝜂𝑡𝜇10𝛽superscript𝐿2superscript𝐵2110subscript𝐿\eta_{t}\leq\frac{\mu}{10\beta L^{2}B^{2}}\wedge\frac{1}{10L_{-}} for all t𝑡t. Then, for both FedAvg and FedProx, there exists some universal constants c,c′𝑐superscript𝑐′c,c^{\prime},

𝔼​‖θt−θ∗‖22≤(1+tγ)−ρ​‖θ0−θ∗‖22+c′​ϵμ2​(G+σ)2+c′​ρ2(ρ−1)​p​μ2​(G+σ)2​1t+γ.𝔼superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝜃𝑡superscript𝜃22superscript1𝑡𝛾𝜌superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝜃0superscript𝜃22superscript𝑐′italic-ϵsuperscript𝜇2superscript𝐺𝜎2superscript𝑐′superscript𝜌2𝜌1𝑝superscript𝜇2superscript𝐺𝜎21𝑡𝛾\mathbb{E}\left\|{\theta_{t}-\theta^{*}}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq\left(1+\frac{t}{\gamma}\right)^{-\rho}\left\|{\theta_{0}-\theta^{*}}\right\|_{2}^{2}+\frac{c^{\prime}\epsilon}{\mu^{2}}\left(G+\sigma\right)^{2}+c^{\prime}\frac{\rho^{2}}{(\rho-1)p\mu^{2}}\left(G+\sigma\right)^{2}\frac{1}{t+\gamma}.

Note that μ/L𝜇𝐿\mu/L is an upper bound to the condition number of Hessian matrix ∇2F.superscript∇2𝐹\nabla^{2}F. Thus, our standing condition B​ϵ<0.8​μL𝐵italic-ϵ0.8𝜇𝐿B\sqrt{\epsilon}<0.8\frac{\mu}{L} indicates that a larger fraction of adversarial dropouts can be tolerated when the population function F𝐹F is better conditioned.

Theorem 3 shows that θtsubscript𝜃𝑡\theta_{t} converges to θ∗superscript𝜃\theta^{*} at a rate of O​(1/t)𝑂1𝑡O(1/t). The O​(1/t)𝑂1𝑡O(1/t) convergence rate is the best possible for any first-order method that has only access to noisy gradients [NJLS09], [GHZH21, Theorem E.1]. When there is no adversarial dropout, our results reduce to the state-of-art convergence results for FedAvg or FedProx. For instance, an exponential decay term similar to (1+t/γ)−ρ​‖θ0−θ∗‖2superscript1𝑡𝛾𝜌subscriptnormsubscript𝜃0superscript𝜃2(1+t/\gamma)^{-\rho}\left\|{\theta_{0}-\theta^{*}}\right\|_{2} and a linear decay term similar to (σ2+G2)/tsuperscript𝜎2superscript𝐺2𝑡(\sigma^{2}+G^{2})/t also appear in [KKM+20, Theorem V]. The convergence results in [LHY+20] are similar but a bit weaker: there is a linear decay term similar to (σ2+G2)/tsuperscript𝜎2superscript𝐺2𝑡(\sigma^{2}+G^{2})/t, but the error bound decays only linearly rather than exponentially in the initial error as ‖θ0−θ∗‖2/tsubscriptnormsubscript𝜃0superscript𝜃2𝑡\left\|{\theta_{0}-\theta^{*}}\right\|_{2}/t.

4.3 Proof sketch of the main theorems

We provide a general proof roadmap of our main theorems and discuss the connections and differences from existing SGD analysis. The sketch focuses on the FedAvg in the general non-convex functions setting. The cases for FedProx or strongly convex functions can be shown via similar arguments.

Following the standard analysis of smooth objective functions,

F​(θt+1)≤F​(θt)+⟨∇F​(θt),θt+1−θt⟩+L2​‖θt+1−θt‖22.𝐹subscript𝜃𝑡1𝐹subscript𝜃𝑡∇𝐹subscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡𝐿2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝜃𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡22F(\theta_{t+1})\leq F(\theta_{t})+\left\langle\nabla F(\theta_{t}),\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t}\right\rangle+\frac{L}{2}\left\|{\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t}}\right\|_{2}^{2}. (10)

The progress over one communication round θt+1−θtsubscript𝜃𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t} per aggregation rule (2) is given by θt+1−θt=β​∑i∈𝒮twi​(θi,t+1−θt).subscript𝜃𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡𝛽subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t}=\beta\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}(\theta_{i,t+1}-\theta_{t}). The classical SGD iteration relies on the unbiasedness of θi,t+1−θtsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡\theta_{i,t+1}-\theta_{t} for the direction of −∇F​(θt)∇𝐹subscript𝜃𝑡-\nabla F(\theta_{t}). The unbiasedness fails to hold due to the following two reasons:

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Objective inconsistency. Under FedAvg or FedProx, the clients either run multiple-step of local SGD or solve a subroutine with proximity regularization. The bias of local updates arises from objective inconsistency or client-drift as analyzed by [WLL+20, KKM+20] for FedAvg. For FedAvg, define

    Bt𝗈𝖻𝗃≜∑i∈𝒮twi​(θi,t+1−θt−(−s​ηt​∇ℓi,t​(θt))).≜superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑡𝗈𝖻𝗃subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡𝑠subscript𝜂𝑡∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡B_{t}^{\sf obj}\triangleq\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}(\theta_{i,t+1}-\theta_{t}-(-s\eta_{t}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t}))).
  • ∙∙\bullet

    Selection bias. Given the sampled clients S~tsubscript~𝑆𝑡\widetilde{S}_{t}, the non-responsive clients 𝒮~t/𝒮tsubscript~𝒮𝑡subscript𝒮𝑡\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}/{\mathcal{S}}_{t} are selected by by the system adversary; consequently, the resulting participating clients 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}_{t} no longer form a representative subset of all clients. What’s more, the adversarial selection is time-varying and may even be correlated with the data used to evaluate the local gradients. Define

    Bt𝗌𝖾𝗅≜∑i∈𝒮~t/𝒮twi​∇ℓi,t​(θt).≜superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑡𝗌𝖾𝗅subscript𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑡subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑤𝑖∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡B_{t}^{\sf sel}\triangleq\sum_{i\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}/{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t}).

Therefore, the major challenge is to quantify the biases from the above two sources carefully.

Objective inconsistency.

We first upper-bound the deviation from the desired direction as

‖θi,t+1−θt−(−s​ηt​∇ℓi,t​(θt))‖2≲s2​ηt2​L​‖∇ℓi,t​(θt)‖2,less-than-or-similar-tosubscriptnormsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡𝑠subscript𝜂𝑡∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡2superscript𝑠2superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2𝐿subscriptnorm∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡2\|{\theta_{i,t+1}-\theta_{t}-(-s\eta_{t}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t}))}\|_{2}\lesssim s^{2}\eta_{t}^{2}L\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})}\right\|_{2},

uniformly for all possible θt,subscript𝜃𝑡\theta_{t}, provided that the local learning rate ηt≲1s​Lless-than-or-similar-tosubscript𝜂𝑡1𝑠𝐿\eta_{t}\lesssim\frac{1}{sL}. The precise result is stated in Lemma 1 in Appendix C.1.1. For each client, the stochastic variation of ‖∇ℓi,t​(θt)−∇Fi​(θt)‖2subscriptnorm∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜃𝑡2\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})-\nabla F_{i}(\theta_{t})}\right\|_{2} follows from (6). Then, by Assumption 1, the collective deviation is upper bounded by

𝔼​[∑i∈𝒮~twi​s2​ηt2​L​‖∇ℓi,t​(θt)‖2∣ℱt]≤p​s2​ηt2​L​(B​‖∇F​(θt)‖2+G+σ).𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑡subscript𝑤𝑖superscript𝑠2superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2𝐿subscriptnorm∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡2subscriptℱ𝑡𝑝superscript𝑠2superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2𝐿𝐵subscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝜃𝑡2𝐺𝜎\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{i\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}s^{2}\eta_{t}^{2}L\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})}\right\|_{2}\mid{\mathcal{F}}_{t}\right]\leq ps^{2}\eta_{t}^{2}L\left(B\|{\nabla F(\theta_{t})}\|_{2}+G+\sigma\right). (11)
Selection bias.

Since 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}_{t} is time-varying and is correlated with ∇ℓi,t​(θt)∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t}), we upper-bound the bias uniformly via the analysis of extreme values. Two main ingredients in our analysis are: 1) the power of the adversary is limited as specified by Assumption 2; 2) the dissimilarity among the clients is bounded given by Assumption 1. Combining those two ingredients, we prove that

𝔼​[‖Bt𝗌𝖾𝗅‖2∣ℱt]≲p​ϵ​(B​‖∇F​(θt)‖2+G+σ)less-than-or-similar-to𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑡𝗌𝖾𝗅2subscriptℱ𝑡𝑝italic-ϵ𝐵subscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝜃𝑡2𝐺𝜎\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|{B_{t}^{\sf sel}}\right\|_{2}\mid{\mathcal{F}}_{t}\right]\lesssim p\sqrt{\epsilon}\left(B\left\|{\nabla F(\theta_{t})}\right\|_{2}+G+\sigma\right) (12)

uniformly over all possible dropout patterns on round t𝑡t. The result is stated in Lemma 2 (presented in Appendix C.1.1). Surprisingly, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-fraction of maliciously chosen unavailable clients can contribute a deviation of O​(ϵ)𝑂italic-ϵO(\sqrt{\epsilon}). The rate turns out to be optimal as the estimation error matches the fundamental limit in Theorem 4.

Combining together.

Once we have tight upper bounds on the bias, the remaining steps are mostly similar to the standard SGD analysis. Specifically,

θt+1−θt=β​∑i∈𝒮twi​(θi,t+1−θt)subscript𝜃𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡𝛽subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡\displaystyle\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t}=\beta\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}(\theta_{i,t+1}-\theta_{t}) =−β​s​ηt​∑i∈𝒮twi​∇ℓi,t​(θt)+β​Bt𝗈𝖻𝗃absent𝛽𝑠subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑤𝑖∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡𝛽superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑡𝗈𝖻𝗃\displaystyle=-\beta s\eta_{t}\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})+\beta B_{t}^{\sf obj}

where 𝔼​[‖Bt𝗈𝖻𝗃‖2|ℱt]𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑡𝗈𝖻𝗃2subscriptℱ𝑡\mathbb{E}[\|{B_{t}^{\sf obj}}\|_{2}|{\mathcal{F}}_{t}] and 𝔼​[‖Bt𝗌𝖾𝗅‖2|ℱt]𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑡𝗌𝖾𝗅2subscriptℱ𝑡\mathbb{E}[\|{B_{t}^{\sf sel}}\|_{2}|{\mathcal{F}}_{t}] are upper bounded by (11) and (12), respectively. Applying the above analysis in (10), we obtain the progress in one communication round, which further yields upper bounds of ‖∇F​(θt)‖2subscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝜃𝑡2\|{\nabla F(\theta_{t})}\|_{2} via suitable scheduling of learning rates. See details in Appendix C.1.

5 Minimax lower bounds

Theorem 4.

Given any algorithm (including randomized and non-FL algorithm) and any time horizon T𝑇T (including T=∞𝑇T=\infty), there always exists a choice of M𝑀M functions {ℓi,t​(θ):i∈[M],t∈[T]}conditional-setsubscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃formulae-sequence𝑖delimited-[]𝑀𝑡delimited-[]𝑇\{\ell_{i,t}(\theta):i\in[M],t\in[T]\} for which i) each ℓi,tsubscriptℓ𝑖𝑡\ell_{i,t} is L𝐿L-smooth and μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex; ii) Fi​(θ)≜𝔼​[ℓi,t​(θ)]≜subscript𝐹𝑖𝜃𝔼delimited-[]subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃F_{i}(\theta)\triangleq\mathbb{E}\left[\ell_{i,t}(\theta)\right] satisfies the (B,G)𝐵𝐺(B,G) condition; iii) 𝗏𝖺𝗋​(∇ℓi,t​(θ))≤σi2𝗏𝖺𝗋∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖\mathsf{var}(\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta))\leq\sigma^{2}_{i}, and a choice of 𝒮t⊂[M]subscript𝒮𝑡delimited-[]𝑀{\mathcal{S}}_{t}\subset[M] for t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T] with |𝒮t|≥(1−ϵ)​Msubscript𝒮𝑡1italic-ϵ𝑀|{\mathcal{S}}_{t}|\geq(1-\epsilon)M such that the output of the algorithm θ^^𝜃\widehat{\theta} given access to {ℓi,t​(θ):i∈𝒮t,t∈[T]}conditional-setsubscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃formulae-sequence𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡𝑡delimited-[]𝑇\{\ell_{i,t}(\theta):i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t},t\in[T]\} has an error at least

𝔼​[ℛ​(θ^)]≥ϵ8​(1−ϵ)​(G2+σ2).𝔼delimited-[]ℛ^𝜃italic-ϵ81italic-ϵsuperscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[{\mathcal{R}}(\widehat{\theta})\right]\geq\frac{\epsilon}{8(1-\epsilon)}\left(G^{2}+\sigma^{2}\right). (13)

We have shown in Theorems 2 and 3 that the lower bound in (13) can be attained by simple variants of the standard FedAvg and FedProx algorithm with only access to noisy gradients and even when the adversary can adaptively choose 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}_{t} based on all the past history information. Combining this result with Theorem 4 implies that ϵ​(G2+σ2)italic-ϵsuperscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2\epsilon\left(G^{2}+\sigma^{2}\right) is minimax optimal.

Proof sketch and comparison of lower bounds. To deduce that the lower bound in (13) is at least on the order of ϵ​G2italic-ϵsuperscript𝐺2\epsilon G^{2}, it suffices to construct time-invariant 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}_{t}. We construct two instances: one homogeneous instance where ℓi,t=fsubscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝑓\ell_{i,t}=f for all i,t𝑖𝑡i,t; and the other heterogeneous instance where ℓi,t=fsubscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝑓\ell_{i,t}=f for i∈S𝑖𝑆i\in S and ℓi,t=gsubscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝑔\ell_{i,t}=g for i∉S𝑖𝑆i\notin S for some fixed S⊂[M]𝑆delimited-[]𝑀S\subset[M] with |S|=(1−ϵ)​M𝑆1italic-ϵ𝑀|S|=(1-\epsilon)M. The functions f𝑓f and g𝑔g are properly chosen to be sufficiently distinct while satisfying the (B,G)𝐵𝐺(B,G)-condition. Importantly, if the adversary chooses 𝒮t=Ssubscript𝒮𝑡𝑆{\mathcal{S}}_{t}=S for all t𝑡t, then any algorithm with access to {ℓi,t:i∈𝒮t}conditional-setsubscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡\{\ell_{i,t}:i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}\} cannot distinguish the two instances and hence cannot simultaneously optimize both instances. A very similar construction of the two instances has been used in [KHJ22, Theorem III] to prove that the same lower bound ϵ​G2italic-ϵsuperscript𝐺2\epsilon G^{2} holds for a static Byzantine attack where the adversary can choose a pre-selected 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}} and corrupt {ℓi,t,i∉𝒮}subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝑖𝒮\{\ell_{i,t},i\notin{\mathcal{S}}\} by arbitrary errors.

In contrast, to prove the lower bound on the order of ϵ​σ2italic-ϵsuperscript𝜎2\epsilon\sigma^{2}, it is crucial to have 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}_{t} be time-varying and chosen based on the realization of {ℓi,t,i∈[M]}subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝑖delimited-[]𝑀\{\ell_{i,t},i\in[M]\}. In particular, we again construct two instances. The first instance is exactly the same as before. The second instance is also the same, except that S𝑆S is replaced by Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t} that is chosen uniformly and independently at random from all subsets of [M]delimited-[]𝑀[M] with size (1−ϵ)​M1italic-ϵ𝑀(1-\epsilon)M. This time the functions f𝑓f and g𝑔g are chosen to be sufficiently distinct while the variance of ∇ℓi,t∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡\nabla\ell_{i,t} is kept at most σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}. Now, if the adversary chooses 𝒮t=Stsubscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑆𝑡{\mathcal{S}}_{t}=S_{t}, then any algorithm with access to {ℓi,t:i∈𝒮t}conditional-setsubscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡\{\ell_{i,t}:i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}\} cannot distinguish the two instances and hence cannot simultaneously optimize both instances. Note that the previous work [KHJ22] assumes the adversary is static and chooses a prefixed 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}} to inject errors; thus the lower bound [KHJ22, Theorem III] does not contain the ϵ​σ2italic-ϵsuperscript𝜎2\epsilon\sigma^{2} term as we do. For this reason, when G=0𝐺0G=0 they show that an FL algorithm with a robust aggregator of noisy gradients can approach the zero optimization error as T→∞→𝑇T\to\infty. However, this is fundamentally impossible in our setting with non-static adversarial dropouts.

Remark 2 (The impact of dissimilarity parameter B𝐵B).

The lower bound in Theorem 4 does not depend on the other dissimilarity parameter B.𝐵B. From the analysis of our algorithm, the parameter B𝐵B in Assumption 1 instead influences the convergence speed and the requirement on the learning rate; the eventual precision is unaffected.

Remark 3 (Convergence rate in T𝑇T).

Our lower bound does not capture the dependency on T.𝑇T. It is known in the literature that even in the centralized homogeneous setting, any algorithm with access to T𝑇T queries of noisy gradients of F𝐹F with variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} has to suffer an estimation error 𝔼​[‖∇F​(θ^)‖22]≥Ω​(σ/T)𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐹^𝜃22Ω𝜎𝑇\mathbb{E}\left[\|\nabla F(\widehat{\theta})\|_{2}^{2}\right]\geq\Omega(\sigma/\sqrt{T}) for non-convex F𝐹F and 𝔼​[‖θ^−θ∗‖2]≥Ω​(μ2​σ2/T)𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm^𝜃superscript𝜃2Ωsuperscript𝜇2superscript𝜎2𝑇\mathbb{E}\left[\|\widehat{\theta}-\theta^{*}\|^{2}\right]\geq\Omega(\mu^{2}\sigma^{2}/T) for μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex F𝐹F in the worst case (see e.g., [ACD+22, Theorem 3] and [GHZH21, Theorem E.1]).

6 Numerical Experiments

In this section, we use numerical experiments to corroborate our theories and analysis on both real-world and synthetic datasets. Specifically, we evaluate the proposed variants of FedAvg and FedProx on balanced real-world dataset (CIFAR-10 [KH+09]) and imbalanced Synthetic (1,1)11\left(1,1\right) dataset (see Appendix E.2) [SSZ14, LSZ+20] with different heterogeneity which will be specified later. The results on synthetic dataset are deferred to Appendix E due to space limitation. In each round, K=10𝐾10K=10 clients are sampled uniformly at random without replacement from M=100𝑀100M=100 clients to build 𝒮~t.subscript~𝒮𝑡\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}. Let us denote by ϵtsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡\epsilon_{t} the actual dropout fraction in round t,𝑡t, i.e., ϵt≜(∑i∈𝒮~t∖𝒮tni)/(K​N/M).≜subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡subscript𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑡subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑛𝑖𝐾𝑁𝑀\epsilon_{t}\triangleq(\sum_{i\in\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}\setminus{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}n_{i})/(KN/M). The amplification factor β𝛽\beta is tuned from grid search and is set as β=M/K=10𝛽𝑀𝐾10\beta=M/K=10 throughout. All the results are averaged from at least two different random seeds. The missing hyper-parameters and hardware setup can be found in the following subsections and in Appendix E.

Each of the evaluations contains two parts:
(1) Comparisons with the baselines: FedAvg [MMR+17], FedProx [LSZ+20], and MIFA [GHZH21] algorithms. Momentum SGD is used as the local solver for FedProx. For ease of presentation, we name FedAvg, MIFA, and our FedAvg variant as FedAvg-type henceforth as they share the same structures of local computations.
(2) Comparisons with Byzantine-resilient algorithms: centered clipping (cclip) [KHJ21], geometric median (GM) [CSX17], and their bucketing variants [KHJ22]. [KHJ22, Section 5] argued that momentum is helpful in reducing clients’ variance in stochastic gradients. This setting is adopted hereafter for the Byzantine-resilient algorithms. Since the original Byzantine-resilient algorithms in [KHJ22] do not account for either partial client participation or local computations, we let the parameter server reuse the inactive clients’ one-step (s=1𝑠1s=1) momentum from the last active rounds, analogous to MIFA, for a fair comparison. The active clients still update their latest momentum to the parameter server for aggregation. Similar to [KHJ22], we set 222 buckets for the bucketing variants.

6.1 Adversarial client unavailability scheme

Recall from Section 3 that the set of participating clients 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}_{t} is constructed as follows. First, the parameter server samples K𝐾K clients uniformly at random without replacement to establish a set 𝒮~t.subscript~𝒮𝑡\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}. Then the system adversary will, subject to satisfying Assumption 2, shrink the set 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t} by selecting some clients to be non-responsive. We aim to have the adversary silence the clients whose gradient changes are the most significant. Towards this, we construct a candidate non-responsive client set 𝒞~~𝒞\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}} based on the executions of two shadow experiments – FedAvg-shadow and cclip-shadow; the set 𝒞~~𝒞\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}} will be used by the adversary to determine time-varying 𝒮~t∖𝒮tsubscript~𝒮𝑡subscript𝒮𝑡\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}\setminus{\mathcal{S}}_{t}. FedAvg-shadow and cclip-shadow are independent executions of FedAvg and cclip yet with full client participation. Their local datasets are independently generated from the same non-IID distributions as those in the regular experiments but using different random seeds. The usage of different random seeds ensures the construction of set 𝒞~~𝒞\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}} does not use future information in regular experiments.

Once the shadow experiments are done, we select the top K1′superscriptsubscript𝐾1′K_{1}^{\prime} clients with the highest |‖∑τ=0s−1∇ℓi,T2τ​(θi,T2τ)‖−‖∑τ=0s−1∇ℓi,T1τ​(θi,T1τ)‖|normsuperscriptsubscript𝜏0𝑠1∇superscriptsubscriptℓ𝑖subscript𝑇2𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝑇2𝜏normsuperscriptsubscript𝜏0𝑠1∇superscriptsubscriptℓ𝑖subscript𝑇1𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝑇1𝜏|\|\sum_{\tau=0}^{s-1}\nabla\ell_{i,T_{2}}^{\tau}\left(\theta_{i,T_{2}}^{\tau}\right)\|-\|\sum_{\tau=0}^{s-1}\nabla\ell_{i,T_{1}}^{\tau}\left(\theta_{i,T_{1}}^{\tau}\right)\|| 222Any pair of round indices with sufficient separation will also work. In fact, our scheme can be readily extended to multiple pairs of such round indices. under FedAvg-shadow to from 𝒞~1subscript~𝒞1\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}_{1}. Similarly, we compute |‖𝒎jT2‖−‖𝒎jT1‖|normsuperscriptsubscript𝒎𝑗subscript𝑇2normsuperscriptsubscript𝒎𝑗subscript𝑇1|\|\bm{m}_{j}^{T_{2}}\|-\|\bm{m}_{j}^{T_{1}}\|| for j∈[M]∖𝒞~1𝑗delimited-[]𝑀subscript~𝒞1j\in[M]\setminus\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}_{1} under cclip-shadow and then choose the top K2′subscriptsuperscript𝐾′2K^{\prime}_{2} clients with the largest momentum changes to form 𝒞~2subscript~𝒞2\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}_{2}. Notably, 𝒞~1∩𝒞~2=∅.subscript~𝒞1subscript~𝒞2\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}_{1}\cap\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}_{2}=\emptyset. Let 𝒞~=𝒞~1∪𝒞~2~𝒞subscript~𝒞1subscript~𝒞2\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}=\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}_{1}\cup\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}_{2} whose |𝒞~|≜K′=K1′+K2′≜~𝒞superscript𝐾′subscriptsuperscript𝐾′1subscriptsuperscript𝐾′2|\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}|\triangleq K^{\prime}=K^{\prime}_{1}+K^{\prime}_{2}.

Now, we are ready to present how the adversary forms 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}_{t} based on C~~𝐶\widetilde{C} and 𝒮~tsubscript~𝒮𝑡\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t} in regular experiments. In each round, let (i1t,…,iKt)subscriptsuperscript𝑖𝑡1…subscriptsuperscript𝑖𝑡𝐾\left(i^{t}_{1},\ldots,i^{t}_{K}\right) denote the indices of the clients in 𝒮t~~subscript𝒮𝑡\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}_{t}} after random permutation, and let 𝒮t′superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑡′{\mathcal{S}}_{t}^{\prime} be an intermediate set which is set as S~tsubscript~𝑆𝑡\widetilde{S}_{t} initially and is used to iteratively build 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}_{t}. For each k𝑘k, the system adversary decides whether to silence client iksubscript𝑖𝑘i_{k} or not based on two criteria: i) ik∈𝒞~subscript𝑖𝑘~𝒞i_{k}\in\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}; ii) ∑i∈(𝒮~t∖𝒮t′)∪{ik}ni≤ϵ​K​N/M.subscript𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑡′subscript𝑖𝑘subscript𝑛𝑖italic-ϵ𝐾𝑁𝑀\sum_{i\in\left(\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}\setminus{{\mathcal{S}}_{t}^{\prime}}\right)\cup\left\{i_{k}\right\}}n_{i}\leq\epsilon KN/M. If both are satisfied, then 𝒮t′←𝒮t′∖{ik}←superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑡′superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑡′subscript𝑖𝑘{\mathcal{S}}_{t}^{\prime}\leftarrow{\mathcal{S}}_{t}^{\prime}\setminus\{i_{k}\}. This procedure is iterated from i1subscript𝑖1i_{1} to iKsubscript𝑖𝐾i_{K} or until |𝒮t′|=1superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑡′1\left|{{\mathcal{S}}_{t}^{\prime}}\right|=1 to avoid trivial boundary case. Finally, 𝒮t←𝒮t′←subscript𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑡′{\mathcal{S}}_{t}\leftarrow{\mathcal{S}}_{t}^{\prime}.

6.2 Experiments on CIFAR-10

Following [HQB19], the CIFAR-10 dataset is partitioned to build each clients’ local datasets according to the Dirichlet allocation with parameter α.𝛼\alpha. The local datasets are balanced with ni=100subscript𝑛𝑖100n_{i}=100 for i∈[M]𝑖delimited-[]𝑀i\in[M] per round. The experiments elapse T=2000𝑇2000T=2000 communication rounds, and all the active clients compute s=25𝑠25s=25 local steps for FedAvg-type in each round. We run the experiments with α=0.1,𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1, which creates highly non-IID local datasets. Only the results with ϵ=0.8italic-ϵ0.8\epsilon=0.8 are presented here, the results with the other choices of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon can be found in Appendix E. We use LeNet-5 [LBBH98] with cross-entropy loss as the network model. The learning rate ηt=η0/t+1subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝜂0𝑡1\eta_{t}=\eta_{0}/\sqrt{t+1} decays with respect to communication rounds with η0subscript𝜂0\eta_{0} tuned from a grid for FedAvg-type, while the others use constant learning rates. We do not use weight decay or the other kinds of learning rate decay. For ease of presentation, the data points are sampled every 15 communication rounds to smooth the plots. The full plot and other details are deferred to Appendix E.

We observe from Fig. 1 that the proposed variants of FedAvg and FedProx outperform all the other algorithms. Compared with the naive FedAvg and FedProx, our variants progress smoother, and the improvements are quite prominent. Notably, MIFA acts better than FedAvg but falls behind our variants. The second row of Fig. 1(a) illustrates that the adversarial client unavailability scheme in Section 6.1 obeys Assumption 2 and creates a highly adversarial environment, where only 222 clients participate in the training per round. On the other hand, the Byzantine-resilient algorithms lag behind the proposed algorithms significantly. Detailed discussions on existing Byzantine-resilient algorithms can be found in Appendix A.

Appendix A Related work on Byzantine-resilient distributed and federated learning

Byzantine attack is a canonical adversary model in distributed computing [Lyn96]. In general, it includes two key aspects: (A.1) adversarial client selection, i.e., the compromised clients can be selected in the worst possible manner based on the knowledge of the system states, and (A.2) malicious value injection, i.e., the compromised clients inject arbitrary values into the system. An illustration can be found in Fig. 2. More importantly, the subset of compromised clients may vary over time [BDPPBT19, Lyn96, CM16], and can be adaptively chosen by the system adversary. Tolerating Byzantine attacks in distributed and federated learning have received intensive attention recently [FXM14, SG15, SV16, BEMGS17, CSX17, YCKB18, XKG19, GMK+20, KHJ21, KHJ22, FGG+22, AFG+23]. Our adversarial unavailability model can be viewed as a special case of Byzantine attacks with adversarial client selection [i.e. (A.1)] but no malicious value injection [i.e.,(A.2)]. Nevertheless, as we explain next, to the best of our knowledge, existing Byzantine-resilient results are not applicable to our problem.

Both (A.1) and (A.2) that are adaptive to history information were considered in [CSX17, YCKB18, SX19] yet under the simplified setting such as IID datasets, strongly-convex objectives, and one-step local updates. To handle the attack adaptivity in both (A.1) and (A.2), algorithm convergence was shown via deriving uniform concentration bounds over the entire model hypothesis set. When the datasets are non-IID or unbalanced, unfortunately, their analysis breaks apart. Assuming the subset of Byzantine clients is fixed and pre-selected throughout training, a more recent line of work [FGG+22, KHJ21, KHJ22] focused on (A.2) only. IID local data is considered in [FGG+22, KHJ21]. Karimireddy et al. [KHJ21] proposed a novel algorithm that uses centered clipping at the parameter server for robust gradient aggregation, and adopts stochastic gradient momentum at each client to enhance robustness against time coupled attacks 333After a close check on the analysis in [KHJ21], we spotted a caveat in their Lemma 9; the clients’ momentum is not independent due to the global model update, which violates the requirements of their Definition C. Consequently, Lemma 9 and Theorem VI in [KHJ21] are problematic.. Extending their convergence analysis to a non-IID setting is challenging unless imposing strong assumptions such as common stationary points (i.e. G=0𝐺0G=0) or absolute bounded gradient dissimilarity (i.e. B=0𝐵0B=0). It is crucial to assume the subset of Byzantine clients is fixed and pre-selected for the analysis in [KHJ22, AFG+23]. When the system adversary can adaptively compromise the clients

the mean of each Byzantine-free bucket in [KHJ22] is no longer unbiased444In each round, the method in [KHJ22] uniformly at random partitions data into multiple buckets. The mathematical correctness of their proposed method requires that, in expectation, the mean of the data in each Byzantine-free bucket is the same as the average of the non-corrupted data, where the expectation is taken over the random data partition. Here a Byzantine-free bucket is a bucket that does not contain any corrupted data. Consider the instance wherein there are four data points {1,2,3,4}1234\{1,2,3,4\}, and at most one of them can be corrupted. Uniformly at random partition the four data points into two groups each with two data points. For each given partition, we choose the group with the larger mean and corrupt the smallest element. A simple enumeration shows that the mean of the Byzantine-free bucket is strictly smaller than the average of non-corrupted data.. To tolerate time-varying subsets of Byzantine clients, the (f,κ)𝑓𝜅(f,\kappa)-robustness in [AFG+23, Definition 2] requirement needs to be imposed on any client subset of proper size, which is hard to ensure unless the involved quantities follow light-tailed distributions such as subgaussian or subexponential [CSX17, YCKB18, SX19].

Appendix B Characterization of convergence speed in the non-convex case

In Corollary 1, the O~​(1/T)~𝑂1𝑇\widetilde{O}(1/\sqrt{T}) convergence rate matches that of the standard stochastic gradient descent for optimizing nonconvex functions [GL13]. In fact, the O​(1/T)𝑂1𝑇O(1/\sqrt{T}) convergence rate is the best possible for any first-order method that has only access to noisy gradients (see e.g. [ACD+22, Theorem 3]). When there is no adversarial dropout, our results in Corollary 1 are comparable to the state-of-the-art convergence results for FedAvg or FedProx. Specifically, For FedAvg, decay terms similar to Δ​B2/TΔsuperscript𝐵2𝑇\Delta B^{2}/T and (G+σ)/T𝐺𝜎𝑇(G+\sigma)/\sqrt{T} also appear in [KKM+20, Thoerem V]. For FedProx, [YL22, Theorem 1] assumes B=0𝐵0B=0 and obtains a decay term similar to (Δ+G2)/TΔsuperscript𝐺2𝑇(\Delta+G^{2})/\sqrt{T}.

Proof of Corollary 1.

In the first case ηt=η0subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝜂0\eta_{t}=\eta_{0} is a constant for a given T𝑇T. We obtain from Theorem 2 that

𝔼​‖∇F​(θR)‖22≤3​Δβ​p​s​T​η0+c​(ϵ+β​s​L​η0)​(G+σ)2.𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝜃𝑅223Δ𝛽𝑝𝑠𝑇subscript𝜂0𝑐italic-ϵ𝛽𝑠𝐿subscript𝜂0superscript𝐺𝜎2\mathbb{E}\|{\nabla F(\theta_{R})}\|_{2}^{2}\leq\frac{3\Delta}{\beta psT\eta_{0}}+c\left(\epsilon+\beta sL\eta_{0}\right)\left(G+\sigma\right)^{2}.

Plugging η0≤1β​p​T​L​(G+σ)subscript𝜂01𝛽𝑝𝑇𝐿𝐺𝜎\eta_{0}\leq\frac{1}{\beta\sqrt{pTL}(G+\sigma)} and 1η0≤10​β​L​B2+β​p​T​L​(G+σ)1subscript𝜂010𝛽𝐿superscript𝐵2𝛽𝑝𝑇𝐿𝐺𝜎\frac{1}{\eta_{0}}\leq 10\beta LB^{2}+\beta\sqrt{pTL}(G+\sigma) yields the desired result.

In the second case ηt=η0/t+1subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝜂0𝑡1\eta_{t}=\eta_{0}/\sqrt{t+1}, it follows from Theorem 2 that

𝔼​‖∇F​(θR)‖22≤3​Δβ​p​s​η0​∑t=0T1t+1+c​(ϵ+β​s​L​η0​∑t=0T1t+1∑t=0T1t+1)​(G+σ)2.𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝜃𝑅223Δ𝛽𝑝𝑠subscript𝜂0superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝑡1𝑐italic-ϵ𝛽𝑠𝐿subscript𝜂0superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝑡1superscript𝐺𝜎2\mathbb{E}\|{\nabla F(\theta_{R})}\|_{2}^{2}\leq\frac{3\Delta}{\beta ps\eta_{0}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\frac{1}{\sqrt{t+1}}}+c\left(\epsilon+\beta sL\eta_{0}\frac{\sum_{t=0}^{T}\frac{1}{{t+1}}}{\sum_{t=0}^{T}\frac{1}{\sqrt{t+1}}}\right)\left(G+\sigma\right)^{2}.

Note that ∑t=0T1t+1=Θ​(T)superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝑡1Θ𝑇\sum_{t=0}^{T}\frac{1}{\sqrt{t+1}}=\Theta(\sqrt{T}) and ∑t=0T1t+1=Θ​(log⁡T)superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝑡1Θ𝑇\sum_{t=0}^{T}\frac{1}{{t+1}}=\Theta(\log T). Plugging η0≤1β​p​L​(G+σ)subscript𝜂01𝛽𝑝𝐿𝐺𝜎\eta_{0}\leq\frac{1}{\beta\sqrt{pL}(G+\sigma)} and 1η0≤10​β​L​B2+β​p​L​(G+σ)1subscript𝜂010𝛽𝐿superscript𝐵2𝛽𝑝𝐿𝐺𝜎\frac{1}{\eta_{0}}\leq{10\beta LB^{2}}+{\beta\sqrt{pL}(G+\sigma)} yields the conclusion. ∎

C.1 Proof of Theorem 2

C.1.1 Preliminary steps and auxiliary lemmas

We first prove the results for the FedAvg update rule. Recall that each Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} is Lisubscript𝐿𝑖L_{i}-smooth. Hence, F𝐹F is L𝐿L-smooth with L=maxi⁡Li𝐿subscript𝑖subscript𝐿𝑖L=\max_{i}L_{i} and thus

F​(θt+1)≤F​(θt)+⟨∇F​(θt),θt+1−θt⟩+L2​‖θt+1−θt‖22.𝐹subscript𝜃𝑡1𝐹subscript𝜃𝑡∇𝐹subscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡𝐿2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝜃𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡22F(\theta_{t+1})\leq F(\theta_{t})+\left\langle\nabla F(\theta_{t}),\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t}\right\rangle+\frac{L}{2}\left\|{\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t}}\right\|_{2}^{2}. (16)

It follows from our aggregation rule (2) that, for every t𝑡t,

θt+1−θtsubscript𝜃𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡\displaystyle\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t} =β​∑i∈𝒮twi​(𝒢i,ts​(θt;ηt)−θt)absent𝛽subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑤𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑖𝑡𝑠subscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡\displaystyle=\beta\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}({\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{s}(\theta_{t};\eta_{t})-\theta_{t})
=β​∑i∈𝒮twi​(𝒢i,ts​(θt;ηt)−θt+s​ηt​∇ℓi,t​(θt))−β​s​ηt​∑i∈𝒮twi​∇ℓi,t​(θt).absent𝛽subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑤𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑖𝑡𝑠subscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡𝑠subscript𝜂𝑡∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡𝛽𝑠subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑤𝑖∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡\displaystyle=\beta\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}({\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{s}(\theta_{t};\eta_{t})-\theta_{t}+s\eta_{t}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t}))-\beta s\eta_{t}\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t}). (17)

On the right-hand side of (17), the second term is similar to the usual stochastic gradient, where we need to deal with the existence of adversarial dropout. Choosing a large s𝑠s increases the negative drift captured in the second term and thus accelerates the training process. However, it also increases the deviation from the stochastic gradient quantified in the first term, and possibly renders training process unstable as observed in [MMR+17]. To quantify the stability of multiple local gradient steps, define

κ≜maxi,t⁡(1+ηt​Li)s−1−s​ηt​Li(s2)​(ηt​Li)2.≜𝜅subscript𝑖𝑡superscript1subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐿𝑖𝑠1𝑠subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐿𝑖binomial𝑠2superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐿𝑖2\kappa\triangleq\max_{i,t}\frac{(1+\eta_{t}L_{i})^{s}-1-s\eta_{t}L_{i}}{\binom{s}{2}(\eta_{t}L_{i})^{2}}.

Intuitively, κ𝜅\kappa characterizes the deviation of multiple local gradient descent from a single gradient descent with a larger step size, as shown in Lemma 1. For the special case that s=1𝑠1s=1, we have κ=0𝜅0\kappa=0; for s≥2𝑠2s\geq 2, it always holds that κ≥1𝜅1\kappa\geq 1. Furthermore, κ≤ec−1−cc2/2𝜅superscript𝑒𝑐1𝑐superscript𝑐22\kappa\leq\frac{e^{c}-1-c}{c^{2}/2} if ηt≤cs​Lsubscript𝜂𝑡𝑐𝑠𝐿\eta_{t}\leq\frac{c}{sL}. We have the following lemma.

Lemma 1.

For s≥1𝑠1s\geq 1, we have

‖θ−𝒢i,ts​(θ;ηt)−s​ηt​∇ℓi,t​(θ)‖2≤κ​ηt2​(s2)​Li​‖∇ℓi,t​(θ)‖2,∀θ.subscriptnorm𝜃superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑖𝑡𝑠𝜃subscript𝜂𝑡𝑠subscript𝜂𝑡∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃2𝜅superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2binomial𝑠2subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptnorm∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃2for-all𝜃\left\|{\theta-{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{s}(\theta;\eta_{t})-s\eta_{t}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}\leq\kappa\eta_{t}^{2}\binom{s}{2}L_{i}\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2},\quad\forall\theta.
Proof.

κ​ηt2​(s2)​Li≥(1+ηt​Li)s−1−s​ηt​LiLi.𝜅superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2binomial𝑠2subscript𝐿𝑖superscript1subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐿𝑖𝑠1𝑠subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐿𝑖subscript𝐿𝑖\kappa\eta_{t}^{2}\binom{s}{2}L_{i}\geq\frac{(1+\eta_{t}L_{i})^{s}-1-s\eta_{t}L_{i}}{L_{i}}.

Hence it suffices to show

‖θ−𝒢i,ts​(θ;ηt)−s​ηt​∇ℓi,t​(θ)‖2≤(1+ηt​Li)s−1−s​ηt​Li(ηt​Li)2​ηt2​Li​‖∇ℓi,t​(θ)‖2.subscriptnorm𝜃superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑖𝑡𝑠𝜃subscript𝜂𝑡𝑠subscript𝜂𝑡∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃2superscript1subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐿𝑖𝑠1𝑠subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐿𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐿𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptnorm∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃2\left\|{\theta-{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{s}(\theta;\eta_{t})-s\eta_{t}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}\leq\frac{(1+\eta_{t}L_{i})^{s}-1-s\eta_{t}L_{i}}{(\eta_{t}L_{i})^{2}}\eta_{t}^{2}L_{i}\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}. (18)

We prove (18) holds for all s≥1𝑠1s\geq 1 by induction. The base case s=1𝑠1s=1 follows from the definition of gradient mapping 𝒢i,tsubscript𝒢𝑖𝑡{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t} in (14). Suppose (18) holds true for s=1,…,n−1𝑠1…𝑛1s=1,\dots,n-1, where n≥2𝑛2n\geq 2. Next we prove (18) for s=n𝑠𝑛s=n. By the telescoping sum

For the second term on the right-hand side of (17), due the adversarial attack, the average of gradients from the participating clients is no longer an unbiased estimate of the population gradient ∇F∇𝐹\nabla F. C.1.2 Bound on the decrease of the objective function

We are ready to analyze the decrease of the objective function values specified on the right-hand side of (16) under our dropout model.

Bounding 𝔼​[⟨∇F​(θt),θt+1−θt⟩∣ℱt]𝔼delimited-[]conditional∇𝐹subscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡subscriptℱ𝑡\mathbb{E}\left[\left\langle\nabla F(\theta_{t}),\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t}\right\rangle\mid{\mathcal{F}}_{t}\right]:

C.1.3 Proof for FedProx

The proof for the FedProx is similar, where we need an analogous result to Lemma 1 under the additional condition that λmin​(∇2ℓi,t​(θ))≥−L−subscript𝜆superscript∇2subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃subscript𝐿\lambda_{\min}(\nabla^{2}\ell_{i,t}(\theta))\geq-L_{-} for all i𝑖i. This condition is standard in analyzing the FedProx algorithm [LHY+20]. Note that the following result and proof can be readily extended to the case where the proximal problem (15) at each local step is solved inexactly (see e.g. [YL22, Lemma 5]).

Lemma 3.

Suppose λmin​(∇2ℓi,t​(θ))≥−L−subscript𝜆superscript∇2subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃subscript𝐿\lambda_{\min}(\nabla^{2}\ell_{i,t}(\theta))\geq-L_{-}. Then for η<1L−𝜂1subscript𝐿\eta<\frac{1}{L_{-}}, we have

‖θ−𝒫i,t​(θ;η)−η​∇ℓi,t​(θ)‖2≤η21−η​L−​Li​‖∇ℓi,t​(θ)‖2,∀θ.subscriptnorm𝜃subscript𝒫𝑖𝑡𝜃𝜂𝜂∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃2superscript𝜂21𝜂subscript𝐿subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptnorm∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃2for-all𝜃\left\|{\theta-{\mathcal{P}}_{i,t}(\theta;\eta)-\eta\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}\leq\frac{\eta^{2}}{1-\eta L_{-}}L_{i}\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2},\quad\forall\theta.
Proof.

For η<1L−𝜂1subscript𝐿\eta<\frac{1}{L_{-}}, the local objective function ℓ~i,t​(z)≜ℓi,t​(z)+12​η​‖z−θ‖22≜subscript~ℓ𝑖𝑡𝑧subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝑧12𝜂superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑧𝜃22\widetilde{\ell}_{i,t}(z)\triangleq\ell_{i,t}(z)+\frac{1}{2\eta}\left\|{z-\theta}\right\|_{2}^{2} as given in (15) is (1/η−L−)1𝜂subscript𝐿(1/\eta-L_{-})-strongly convex in view of the definition (9). Hence, the optimization program (15) has a unique minimizer. By the first-order optimality condition,

θ−𝒫i,t​(θ,η)=η​∇ℓi,t​(𝒫i,t​(θ,η)).𝜃subscript𝒫𝑖𝑡𝜃𝜂𝜂∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡subscript𝒫𝑖𝑡𝜃𝜂\theta-{\mathcal{P}}_{i,t}(\theta,\eta)=\eta\nabla\ell_{i,t}({\mathcal{P}}_{i,t}(\theta,\eta)).

By the (1η−L−)1𝜂subscript𝐿(\frac{1}{\eta}-L_{-})-strong convexity of the objective function ℓ~i,t​(z)subscript~ℓ𝑖𝑡𝑧\widetilde{\ell}_{i,t}(z), we have

‖𝒫i,t​(θ,η)−θ‖2≤11η−L−​‖∇ℓ~i,t​(𝒫i,t​(θ,η))−∇ℓ~i,t​(θ)‖2=11η−L−​‖∇ℓi,t​(θ)‖2,subscriptnormsubscript𝒫𝑖𝑡𝜃𝜂𝜃211𝜂subscript𝐿subscriptnorm∇subscript~ℓ𝑖𝑡subscript𝒫𝑖𝑡𝜃𝜂∇subscript~ℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃211𝜂subscript𝐿subscriptnorm∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃2\left\|{{\mathcal{P}}_{i,t}(\theta,\eta)-\theta}\right\|_{2}\leq\frac{1}{\frac{1}{\eta}-L_{-}}\left\|{\nabla\widetilde{\ell}_{i,t}({\mathcal{P}}_{i,t}(\theta,\eta))-\nabla\widetilde{\ell}_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}=\frac{1}{\frac{1}{\eta}-L_{-}}\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2},

where we used the facts that ∇ℓ~i,t​(𝒫i,t​(θ,η))=0∇subscript~ℓ𝑖𝑡subscript𝒫𝑖𝑡𝜃𝜂0\nabla\widetilde{\ell}_{i,t}({\mathcal{P}}_{i,t}(\theta,\eta))=0 and ∇ℓ~i,t​(θ)=∇ℓi,t​(θ)∇subscript~ℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃\nabla\widetilde{\ell}_{i,t}(\theta)=\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta). Therefore, by the smoothness of ℓi,tsubscriptℓ𝑖𝑡\ell_{i,t}, we have

‖θ−𝒫i,t​(θ,η)−η​∇ℓi,t​(θ)‖2subscriptnorm𝜃subscript𝒫𝑖𝑡𝜃𝜂𝜂∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃2\displaystyle\left\|{\theta-{\mathcal{P}}_{i,t}(\theta,\eta)-\eta\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2} =η​‖∇ℓi,t​(𝒫i,t​(θ,η))−∇ℓi,t​(θ)‖2≤η​Li​‖𝒫i,t​(θ,η)−θ‖2absent𝜂subscriptnorm∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡subscript𝒫𝑖𝑡𝜃𝜂∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃2𝜂subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptnormsubscript𝒫𝑖𝑡𝜃𝜂𝜃2\displaystyle=\eta\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}({\mathcal{P}}_{i,t}(\theta,\eta))-\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}\leq\eta L_{i}\left\|{{\mathcal{P}}_{i,t}(\theta,\eta)-\theta}\right\|_{2}
≤η2​Li1−η​L−​‖∇ℓi,t​(θ)‖2.∎absentsuperscript𝜂2subscript𝐿𝑖1𝜂subscript𝐿subscriptnorm∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃2\displaystyle\leq\frac{\eta^{2}L_{i}}{1-\eta L_{-}}\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}.\qed

The remaining analysis is similar to the FedAvg update rule. In particular, following the previous arguments, we upper bound the right-hand side of (16) by

C.2 Proof of Theorem 3

Proof of Theorem 3.

We first consider FedAvg. The proof is in the same spirit as that in the non-convex case.
