Appendix D Proofs of lower bounds in Theorem 4

Lower bound 1

We first construct the hard instances and prove the lower bounds

𝔼​‖∇F​(θ^)‖22≥ϵ​G24​(1−ϵ),and​𝔼​‖θ^−θ∗‖22≥ϵ​G24​μ2​(1−ϵ),formulae-sequence𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐹^𝜃22italic-ϵsuperscript𝐺241italic-ϵand𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm^𝜃superscript𝜃22italic-ϵsuperscript𝐺24superscript𝜇21italic-ϵ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\|{\nabla F\left(\widehat{\theta}\right)}\right\|_{2}^{2}\geq\frac{\epsilon G^{2}}{4(1-\epsilon)},~{}~{}\text{and}~{}~{}\mathbb{E}\left\|{\widehat{\theta}-\theta^{*}}\right\|_{2}^{2}\geq\frac{\epsilon G^{2}}{4\mu^{2}(1-\epsilon)}, (40)

with uniform weights wi=1Msubscript𝑤𝑖1𝑀w_{i}=\frac{1}{M}. We assume the PS selects all clients, among which an arbitrary ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-fraction can drop out in each round. Define

f​(θ)=L2​‖θ‖22,g​(θ)=L2​‖θ+uL‖22,formulae-sequence𝑓𝜃𝐿2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜃22𝑔𝜃𝐿2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜃𝑢𝐿22f(\theta)=\frac{L}{2}\left\|{\theta}\right\|_{2}^{2},\qquad g(\theta)=\frac{L}{2}\left\|{\theta+\frac{u}{L}}\right\|_{2}^{2}, (41)

where u𝑢u is a fixed vector to be determined. Consider the following two instances:

  • •

    Instance 1 (homogeneous case): Let ℓi,t​(θ)=f​(θ)subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃𝑓𝜃\ell_{i,t}(\theta)=f(\theta) for all i,t𝑖𝑡i,t;

  • •

    Instance 2 (heterogeneous case): Let 𝒮⊆[M]𝒮delimited-[]𝑀{\mathcal{S}}\subseteq[M] be a subset with cardinality ⌊(1−ϵ)​M⌋1italic-ϵ𝑀\lfloor{(1-\epsilon)M}\rfloor. Let

    ℓi,t​(θ)={f​(θ),i∈𝒮,∀t,g​(θ),i∉𝒮,∀t.subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃cases𝑓𝜃𝑖𝒮for-all𝑡𝑔𝜃𝑖𝒮for-all𝑡\ell_{i,t}(\theta)=\begin{cases}f(\theta),&i\in{\mathcal{S}},~{}\forall t,\\ g(\theta),&i\not\in{\mathcal{S}},~{}\forall t.\end{cases}

Apparently, the two instances are indistinguishable if the adversary blocks all clients belonging to 𝒮csuperscript𝒮𝑐{\mathcal{S}}^{c} in every round. Therefore, any algorithm must output the same θ^^𝜃\widehat{\theta} under those two instances (a randomized algorithm outputs θ^^𝜃\widehat{\theta} with the same distribution).

Next we evaluate the objective functions in those two instances. It can be readily computed that

∇f​(θ)=L​θ,∇g​(θ)=L​θ+u=∇f​(θ)+u.formulae-sequence∇𝑓𝜃𝐿𝜃∇𝑔𝜃𝐿𝜃𝑢∇𝑓𝜃𝑢\nabla f(\theta)=L\theta,\qquad\nabla g(\theta)=L\theta+u=\nabla f(\theta)+u.

Let F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} and F2subscript𝐹2F_{2} denote the global objective functions of the two instances, respectively. Then we have

∇F1​(θ)=∇f​(θ),∇F2​(θ)=∇f​(θ)+ϵ​u.formulae-sequence∇subscript𝐹1𝜃∇𝑓𝜃∇subscript𝐹2𝜃∇𝑓𝜃italic-ϵ𝑢\nabla F_{1}(\theta)=\nabla f(\theta),\qquad\nabla F_{2}(\theta)=\nabla f(\theta)+\epsilon u.

By the triangle inequality,

‖∇F1​(θ)‖2+‖∇F2​(θ)‖2≥ϵ​‖u‖2,∀θ.subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹1𝜃2subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹2𝜃2italic-ϵsubscriptnorm𝑢2for-all𝜃\left\|{\nabla F_{1}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}+\left\|{\nabla F_{2}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}\geq\epsilon\left\|{u}\right\|_{2},\quad\forall\theta.

Consequently, for any θ^^𝜃\widehat{\theta}, we have

max⁡{𝔼​‖∇F1​(θ^)‖2,𝔼​‖∇F2​(θ^)‖2}≥𝔼​‖∇F1​(θ^)‖2+𝔼​‖∇F1​(θ^)‖22≥ϵ2​‖u‖2.𝔼subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹1^𝜃2𝔼subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹2^𝜃2𝔼subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹1^𝜃2𝔼subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹1^𝜃22italic-ϵ2subscriptnorm𝑢2\max\left\{\mathbb{E}\|{\nabla F_{1}(\widehat{\theta})}\|_{2},\mathbb{E}\|{\nabla F_{2}(\widehat{\theta})}\|_{2}\right\}\geq\frac{\mathbb{E}\|{\nabla F_{1}(\widehat{\theta})}\|_{2}+\mathbb{E}\|{\nabla F_{1}(\widehat{\theta})}\|_{2}}{2}\geq\frac{\epsilon}{2}\left\|{u}\right\|_{2}.

Furthermore, both f𝑓f and g𝑔g are μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex with μ=L.𝜇𝐿\mu=L. The minimizers of F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} and F2subscript𝐹2F_{2} are θ1∗=0superscriptsubscript𝜃10\theta_{1}^{*}=0 and θ2∗=−u​ϵ/Lsuperscriptsubscript𝜃2𝑢italic-ϵ𝐿\theta_{2}^{*}=-u\epsilon/L, respectively. Therefore, we similarly obtain that

max⁡{𝔼​‖θ^−θ1∗‖2,𝔼​‖θ^−θ2∗‖2}≥𝔼​‖θ^−θ1∗‖2+𝔼​‖θ^−θ2∗‖22≥‖θ1∗−θ2∗‖22=ϵ2​L​‖u‖2.𝔼subscriptnorm^𝜃superscriptsubscript𝜃12𝔼subscriptnorm^𝜃superscriptsubscript𝜃22𝔼subscriptnorm^𝜃superscriptsubscript𝜃1∗2𝔼subscriptnorm^𝜃superscriptsubscript𝜃222subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜃1∗superscriptsubscript𝜃2∗22italic-ϵ2𝐿subscriptnorm𝑢2\max\left\{\mathbb{E}\|{{\widehat{\theta}}-\theta_{1}^{*}}\|_{2},\mathbb{E}\|{{\widehat{\theta}}-\theta_{2}^{*}}\|_{2}\right\}\geq\frac{\mathbb{E}\|{\widehat{\theta}-\theta_{1}^{\ast}}\|_{2}+\mathbb{E}\|{\widehat{\theta}-\theta_{2}^{*}}\|_{2}}{2}\geq\frac{\|{\theta_{1}^{\ast}-\theta_{2}^{\ast}}\|_{2}}{2}=\frac{\epsilon}{2L}\left\|{u}\right\|_{2}.

It remains to choose u𝑢u and verify the heterogeneity condition in Assumption 1. The heterogeneity condition trivially holds on the first instance, so we only need to verify the second instance. To get the best lower bound, it boils to finding the largest ‖u‖2subscriptnorm𝑢2\left\|{u}\right\|_{2} such that the second instance fulfills Assumption 1, that is, the optimal value of the following program:

ℰ∗≜max≜superscriptℰ\displaystyle{\mathcal{E}}^{*}\triangleq\max (12​ϵ​‖u‖2)2superscript12italic-ϵsubscriptnorm𝑢22\displaystyle~{}~{}\left(\frac{1}{2}\epsilon\left\|{u}\right\|_{2}\right)^{2}
s.t. (1−ϵ)​‖∇f​(θ)‖22+ϵ​‖∇g​(θ)‖22≤B2​‖∇F2​(θ)‖22+G2,∀θ.1italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑓𝜃22italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑔𝜃22superscript𝐵2superscriptsubscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹2𝜃22superscript𝐺2for-all𝜃\displaystyle~{}~{}(1-\epsilon)\left\|{\nabla f(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}+\epsilon\left\|{\nabla g(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq B^{2}\left\|{\nabla F_{2}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}+G^{2},\quad\forall\theta.

To this end, we find sufficient conditions for the feasible set of u𝑢u:

(1−ϵ)​‖∇f​(θ)‖22+ϵ​‖∇g​(θ)‖22≤B2​‖∇F2​(θ)‖22+G2,∀θ,1italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑓𝜃22italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑔𝜃22superscript𝐵2superscriptsubscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹2𝜃22superscript𝐺2for-all𝜃\displaystyle~{}(1-\epsilon)\left\|{\nabla f(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}+\epsilon\left\|{\nabla g(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq B^{2}\left\|{\nabla F_{2}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}+G^{2},\quad\forall\theta,
⇔⇔\displaystyle\Leftrightarrow ‖∇f​(θ)‖22+ϵ​‖u‖22+2​ϵ​⟨∇f​(θ),u⟩≤B2​‖∇f​(θ)‖22+ϵ2​B2​‖u‖22+2​ϵ​B2​⟨∇f​(θ),u⟩+G2,∀θ,superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑓𝜃22italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscriptnorm𝑢222italic-ϵ∇𝑓𝜃𝑢superscript𝐵2superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑓𝜃22superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript𝐵2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑢222italic-ϵsuperscript𝐵2∇𝑓𝜃𝑢superscript𝐺2for-all𝜃\displaystyle~{}\left\|{\nabla f(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}+\epsilon\left\|{u}\right\|_{2}^{2}+2\epsilon\left\langle\nabla f(\theta),u\right\rangle\leq B^{2}\left\|{\nabla f(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}+\epsilon^{2}B^{2}\left\|{u}\right\|_{2}^{2}+2\epsilon B^{2}\left\langle\nabla f(\theta),u\right\rangle+G^{2},\quad\forall\theta,
⇔⇔\displaystyle\Leftrightarrow (ϵ−B2​ϵ2)​‖u‖22≤minθ⁡(B2−1)​(‖∇f​(θ)‖22+2​ϵ​⟨∇f​(θ),u⟩)+G2.italic-ϵsuperscript𝐵2superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑢22subscript𝜃superscript𝐵21superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑓𝜃222italic-ϵ∇𝑓𝜃𝑢superscript𝐺2\displaystyle~{}(\epsilon-B^{2}\epsilon^{2})\left\|{u}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq\min_{\theta}(B^{2}-1)(\left\|{\nabla f(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}+2\epsilon\left\langle\nabla f(\theta),u\right\rangle)+G^{2}. (42)

Recall that B≥1𝐵1B\geq 1 and

‖∇f​(θ)‖22+2​ϵ​⟨∇f​(θ),u⟩=‖∇f​(θ)+ϵ​u‖22−ϵ2​‖u‖22≥−ϵ2​‖u‖22.superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑓𝜃222italic-ϵ∇𝑓𝜃𝑢superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑓𝜃italic-ϵ𝑢22superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑢22superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑢22\left\|{\nabla f(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}+2\epsilon\left\langle\nabla f(\theta),u\right\rangle=\left\|{\nabla f(\theta)+\epsilon u}\right\|_{2}^{2}-\epsilon^{2}\left\|{u}\right\|_{2}^{2}\geq-\epsilon^{2}\left\|{u}\right\|_{2}^{2}.

Therefore, a sufficient condition for the constraint on u𝑢u is

(ϵ−B2​ϵ2)​‖u‖22≤−(B2−1)​ϵ2​‖u‖22+G2italic-ϵsuperscript𝐵2superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑢22superscript𝐵21superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑢22superscript𝐺2\displaystyle~{}(\epsilon-B^{2}\epsilon^{2})\left\|{u}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq-(B^{2}-1)\epsilon^{2}\left\|{u}\right\|_{2}^{2}+G^{2}
⇔⇔\displaystyle\Leftrightarrow (ϵ−ϵ2)​‖u‖22≤G2.italic-ϵsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑢22superscript𝐺2\displaystyle~{}(\epsilon-\epsilon^{2})\left\|{u}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq G^{2}.

We obtain that ℰ∗≥ϵ2​G24​(ϵ−ϵ2)superscriptℰsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript𝐺24italic-ϵsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2{\mathcal{E}}^{*}\geq\frac{\epsilon^{2}G^{2}}{4(\epsilon-\epsilon^{2})} and thus the desired (40).

Lower bound 2

Next, we establish the lower bounds

𝔼​‖∇F​(θ^)‖22≥ϵ​σ24​(1−ϵ),𝔼​‖θ^−θ∗‖22≥ϵ​σ24​μ2​(1−ϵ).formulae-sequence𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐹^𝜃22italic-ϵsuperscript𝜎241italic-ϵ𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm^𝜃superscript𝜃22italic-ϵsuperscript𝜎24superscript𝜇21italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}\left\|{\nabla F\left(\widehat{\theta}\right)}\right\|_{2}^{2}\geq\frac{\epsilon\sigma^{2}}{4(1-\epsilon)},\qquad\mathbb{E}\left\|{\widehat{\theta}-\theta^{*}}\right\|_{2}^{2}\geq\frac{\epsilon\sigma^{2}}{4\mu^{2}(1-\epsilon)}.

Again we construct the hard instances based on (41) and prove the lower bounds with uniform weights wi=1subscript𝑤𝑖1w_{i}=1 and noise variance σi=σ.subscript𝜎𝑖𝜎\sigma_{i}=\sigma. In (41), let u𝑢u be a fixed vector to be determined. Consider the following two instances:

  • •

    Instance 1 (noiseless case): Let ℓi,t​(θ)=f​(θ)subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃𝑓𝜃\ell_{i,t}(\theta)=f(\theta) for all i,t𝑖𝑡i,t;

  • •

    Instance 2 (noisy case): Choose St⊂[M]subscript𝑆𝑡delimited-[]𝑀S_{t}\subset[M] uniformly at random from all possible subsets with cardinality ⌊(1−ϵ)​M⌋.1italic-ϵ𝑀\lfloor(1-\epsilon)M\rfloor.

    ℓi,t​(θ)={f​(θ),i∈St,g​(θ),i∈Stc.subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃cases𝑓𝜃𝑖subscript𝑆𝑡𝑔𝜃𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑡𝑐\ell_{i,t}(\theta)=\begin{cases}f(\theta),&i\in S_{t},\\ g(\theta),&i\in S_{t}^{c}.\end{cases}

In t𝑡t-th round, the adversary inspects the realization of Xi,tsubscript𝑋𝑖𝑡X_{i,t} and drops all clients in Stcsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑡𝑐S_{t}^{c}. Hence, the fraction of dropping-out clients is at most ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, and the two instances are indistinguishable.

Next we evaluate the difference between the global objective functions in those two instances denoted by F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} and F2subscript𝐹2F_{2}, respectively. By definition,

∇F1​(θ)=L​θ,∇F2​(θ)=(1−ϵ)​∇f​(θ)+ϵ​∇g​(θ)=L​θ+ϵ​u.formulae-sequence∇subscript𝐹1𝜃𝐿𝜃∇subscript𝐹2𝜃1italic-ϵ∇𝑓𝜃italic-ϵ∇𝑔𝜃𝐿𝜃italic-ϵ𝑢\nabla F_{1}(\theta)=L\theta,\qquad\nabla F_{2}(\theta)=(1-\epsilon)\nabla f(\theta)+\epsilon\nabla g(\theta)=L\theta+\epsilon u.

Following the argument in Theorem 4, for any θ^^𝜃\widehat{\theta}, we have

max⁡{𝔼​‖∇F1​(θ^)‖2,𝔼​‖∇F2​(θ^)‖2}≥𝔼​‖∇F1​(θ^)‖2+𝔼​‖∇F1​(θ^)‖22≥ϵ2​‖u‖2.𝔼subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹1^𝜃2𝔼subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹2^𝜃2𝔼subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹1^𝜃2𝔼subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹1^𝜃22italic-ϵ2subscriptnorm𝑢2\max\left\{\mathbb{E}\|{\nabla F_{1}(\widehat{\theta})}\|_{2},\mathbb{E}\|{\nabla F_{2}(\widehat{\theta})}\|_{2}\right\}\geq\frac{\mathbb{E}\|{\nabla F_{1}(\widehat{\theta})}\|_{2}+\mathbb{E}\|{\nabla F_{1}(\widehat{\theta})}\|_{2}}{2}\geq\frac{\epsilon}{2}\left\|{u}\right\|_{2}.

Similarly, both f𝑓f and g𝑔g are μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex with μ=L.𝜇𝐿\mu=L. The minimizers of F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} and F2subscript𝐹2F_{2} are θ1∗=0superscriptsubscript𝜃10\theta_{1}^{*}=0 and θ2∗=−u​ϵ/Lsuperscriptsubscript𝜃2𝑢italic-ϵ𝐿\theta_{2}^{*}=-u\epsilon/L, respectively. Therefore,

max⁡{𝔼​‖θ^−θ1∗‖2,𝔼​‖θ^−θ2∗‖2}≥𝔼​‖θ^−θ1∗‖2+𝔼​‖θ^−θ2∗‖22≥ϵ2​L​‖u‖2.𝔼subscriptnorm^𝜃superscriptsubscript𝜃12𝔼subscriptnorm^𝜃superscriptsubscript𝜃22𝔼subscriptnorm^𝜃superscriptsubscript𝜃12𝔼subscriptnorm^𝜃superscriptsubscript𝜃222italic-ϵ2𝐿subscriptnorm𝑢2\max\left\{\mathbb{E}\|{{\widehat{\theta}}-\theta_{1}^{*}}\|_{2},\mathbb{E}\|{{\widehat{\theta}}-\theta_{2}^{*}}\|_{2}\right\}\geq\frac{\mathbb{E}\|{{\widehat{\theta}}-\theta_{1}^{*}}\|_{2}+\mathbb{E}\|{{\widehat{\theta}}-\theta_{2}^{*}}\|_{2}}{2}\geq\frac{\epsilon}{2L}\left\|{u}\right\|_{2}.

The clients in both instances are homogeneous and thus fulfills Assumption 1. It remains to evaluate the variance of the noisy gradients in the second instance. To get the best lower bound, it boils down to finding the optimal value of the following program:

ℰ∗≜max≜superscriptℰ\displaystyle{\mathcal{E}}^{*}\triangleq\max (12​ϵ​‖u‖2)2superscript12italic-ϵsubscriptnorm𝑢22\displaystyle~{}~{}\left(\frac{1}{2}\epsilon\left\|{u}\right\|_{2}\right)^{2}
s.t. 𝗏𝖺𝗋​[∇ℓi,t​(θ)]≤σ2.𝗏𝖺𝗋delimited-[]∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃superscript𝜎2\displaystyle~{}~{}\mathsf{var}\left[\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)\right]\leq\sigma^{2}.

Following the definition of ℓi,tsubscriptℓ𝑖𝑡\ell_{i,t}, we have

𝗏𝖺𝗋​[∇ℓi,t​(θ)]=ϵ​(1−ϵ)​‖u‖22≤σ2.𝗏𝖺𝗋delimited-[]∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑡𝜃italic-ϵ1italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscriptnorm𝑢22superscript𝜎2\mathsf{var}\left[\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)\right]=\epsilon(1-\epsilon)\left\|{u}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq\sigma^{2}.

Therefore, ℰ∗≥ϵ2​σ24​ϵ​(1−ϵ)superscriptℰsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript𝜎24italic-ϵ1italic-ϵ{\mathcal{E}}^{*}\geq\frac{\epsilon^{2}\sigma^{2}}{4\epsilon(1-\epsilon)}.

Remark 4.

If the objective functions are not required to be strongly convex, the above construction of hard instances can be extended to show the necessity of ϵ​B2≤O​(1)italic-ϵsuperscript𝐵2𝑂1\epsilon B^{2}\leq O(1) as required in our main theorems. In particular, similar arguments continue for a general pair of functions f𝑓f and g𝑔g satisfying ∇g​(θ)=∇f​(θ)+u∇𝑔𝜃∇𝑓𝜃𝑢\nabla g(\theta)=\nabla f(\theta)+u. Suppose ∇f​(θ)∇𝑓𝜃\nabla f(\theta) lies in some linear subspace that is orthogonal to u𝑢u, so that ⟨∇f​(θ),u⟩=0.∇𝑓𝜃𝑢0\left\langle\nabla f(\theta),u\right\rangle=0. If ϵ​B2>1italic-ϵsuperscript𝐵21\epsilon B^{2}>1, then (42) and thus Assumption 1 are always satisfied regardless of ‖u‖2subscriptnorm𝑢2\left\|{u}\right\|_{2}, which yields a lower bound of ∞\infty. Therefore, under a more heterogeneous environment, the federated learning system should be better protected from adversarial dropout.

Appendix E Experiments

In this section, we provide the detailed setups and additional experiments.

Hardware Setups: we run all the experiments on a cluster with 8 Tesla V100 Volta GPUs and 80 Intel Xeon E5 CPUs. The codes are built upon PyTorch 1.13.1 [PGM+19].

Hyper-parameters: the hyper-parameters are tuned from grid searches: initial learning rates η0∈{10−4,…,10−1},subscript𝜂0superscript104…superscript101\eta_{0}\in\left\{10^{-4},\ldots,10^{-1}\right\}, amplification factor β∈{1,10,…,100},𝛽110…100\beta\in\left\{1,10,\ldots,100\right\}, the proximal coefficient μ0≜1ηt∈{10−3,…,1},≜subscript𝜇01subscript𝜂𝑡superscript103…1\mu_{0}\triangleq\frac{1}{\eta_{t}}\in\left\{10^{-3},\ldots,1\right\}, the observation windows are set to be T1=5subscript𝑇15T_{1}=5 and T2=150,subscript𝑇2150T_{2}=150, the selection candidate volumes are K1′=25,K2′=10.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐾1′25superscriptsubscript𝐾2′10K_{1}^{\prime}=25,K_{2}^{\prime}=10.

Additionally, we list some key elements in Table 1 to avoid confusion, where η0subscript𝜂0\eta_{0} denotes a constant learning rate but may not refer to the same value for different algorithms. For the numerical calculation of GM, we adopt the smoothed Weiszfeld algorithm from [PKH22]. Note that the iterative centered clipping rule is modified as (43) to adapt to imbalanced training data:

𝒗l+1=𝒗l+∑i=1Mwi​(θi−𝒗l)​min⁡(1,τl‖θi−𝒗l‖2),subscript𝒗𝑙1subscript𝒗𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝒗𝑙1subscript𝜏𝑙subscriptnormsubscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝒗𝑙2\displaystyle\bm{v}_{l+1}=\bm{v}_{l}+\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}\left(\theta_{i}-\bm{v}_{l}\right)\min\left(1,\frac{\tau_{l}}{\left\|{\theta_{i}-\bm{v}_{l}}\right\|_{2}}\right), (43)

where the choice of τl=101−β0subscript𝜏𝑙101subscript𝛽0\tau_{l}=\frac{10}{1-\beta_{0}} follows from [KHJ22], and β0subscript𝛽0\beta_{0} is the momentum coefficient.

Likewise, Line 9 in Algorithm 1 of [GHZH21] is modified as (44).

θt+1=θt−ηt​∑i=1Mwi​Gi.subscript𝜃𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖superscript𝐺𝑖\displaystyle\theta_{t+1}=\theta_{t}-\eta_{t}\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}G^{i}. (44)

E.1 CIFAR-10

In this section, we present the additional results on CIFAR-10 dataset. Fig. 3 and 4 show the non-smoothed experimental results.

Similar to Section 6.2, we first present the smoothed curves with ϵ=0.2italic-ϵ0.2\epsilon=0.2 in Fig. 5 and 6 by sampling every 151515 data points for a clear presentation on the trend. Next, the non-smoothed ones are shown in Fig. 7.

Generally, the observations resemble those from the case of ϵ=0.8.italic-ϵ0.8\epsilon=0.8. Our variants’ trajectories are less noisy than the naive FedAvg and FedProx algorithms. In the baseline comparisons, all the FedAvg-type algorithms achieve comparable performance, while our FedProx variant achieves the best test accuracy. Meanwhile, the Byzantine-robust algorithms, except the naive GM, reach similar results as well. This is intuitive as a total of 888 clients participate in the training per round, which is suggested by the second row of Fig. 5 and in sharp contrast to the highly adversarial case of ϵ=0.8,italic-ϵ0.8\epsilon=0.8, where only 222 clients are in the set 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}_{t}.

E.2 Synthetic (1,1)11(1,1)

Overview: Synthetic (1,1) was introduced in [SSZ14, LSZ+20] for FL. We generate samples (Xi,Yi)subscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑌𝑖(X_{i},Y_{i}) for each client i𝑖i according to the model y=arg⁡max⁡(softmax​(W​x+b)),𝑦softmax𝑊𝑥𝑏y=\arg\max\left(\text{softmax}\left(Wx+b\right)\right), where x∈ℝ60,𝑥superscriptℝ60x\in{\mathbb{R}}^{60}, W∈ℝ10×60,𝑊superscriptℝ1060W\in{\mathbb{R}}^{10\times 60}, b∈ℝ10.𝑏superscriptℝ10b\in{\mathbb{R}}^{10}. To characterize the non-i.i.d. data, we let Wi∼N​(ui,1),bi∼N​(ui,1),ui∼N​(0,α=1),formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscript𝑊𝑖𝑁subscript𝑢𝑖1formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscript𝑏𝑖𝑁subscript𝑢𝑖1similar-tosubscript𝑢𝑖𝑁0𝛼1W_{i}\sim N\left(u_{i},1\right),~{}b_{i}\sim N\left(u_{i},1\right),~{}u_{i}\sim N\left(0,\alpha=1\right), and xi∼𝒩​(vi,Σ),similar-tosubscript𝑥𝑖𝒩subscript𝑣𝑖Σx_{i}\sim{\mathcal{N}}\left(v_{i},\Sigma\right), where the covariance matrix is diagonal with ∑j,j=j−1.2.subscript𝑗𝑗superscript𝑗1.2\sum_{j,j}=j^{-1.2}. Each element in the mean vector visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} is drawn from N​(Bi,1),𝑁subscript𝐵𝑖1N\left(B_{i},1\right), where Bi∼N​(0,β=1).similar-tosubscript𝐵𝑖𝑁0𝛽1B_{i}\sim N\left(0,\beta=1\right). Each clients’ data volume follows a power law as shown in Fig. 8.

Implementation: we consider multi-nomial Logistic regression with full batch gradient descent and cross-entropy loss. That is, client i𝑖i’s batch size equals to its data volume ni.subscript𝑛𝑖n_{i}.

Interpretations: the first row of Fig. 9 shows the results without MIFA, whereas the second row is with MIFA. Although the test accuracies in the first row are similar, our variants achieve lower train loss when compared with the naive FedAvg and FedProx.

Due to the imbalance, we cannot guarantee an almost constant dropout fraction ϵtsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡\epsilon_{t} like in the balanced CIFAR-10 experiments. This is because the sampled clients’ data volumes are time-varying in each round. It is possible that the client with the least many data points holds a larger data volume than the threshold ϵ​K​N/M,italic-ϵ𝐾𝑁𝑀\epsilon KN/M, and thus no one is droppoed out during that round. However, the dropout scheme ensures that maxt∈[T]⁡ϵt≤ϵsubscript𝑡delimited-[]𝑇subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡italic-ϵ\max_{t\in[T]}\epsilon_{t}\leq\epsilon as suggested by the second row of Fig. 9.

MIFA’s curve resembles a roller coaster ride and does not converge till the end of training. Similarly, Fig. 10 tells us that the Byzantine-robust algorithms’ fluctuations, which are consistently noisy and do not abate throughout the training, are also severe. A similar trend can be observed from Fig. 11 and 12.

Conclusion Remark: we evaluate the proposed variants on both synthetic and real-world data. In all the experiments, the proposed variants progress smoothly and achieve great, if not best, performance. More importantly, the performance does not demand additional memory, unlike MIFA or the Byzantine-robust MIFA variants.
